content.webTitle: Fabio Capello: World Cup owes England for goalline technology

fields.headline: Fabio Capello: World Cup owes England for goalline technology
fields.bodyText: Fabio Capello believes the World Cup owes England a debt of gratitude for the gift of goalline technology and has said only Fifa had to change, not himself, after his team’s dismal exit from the 2010 finals. The Italian endured rare personal failure as England manager in South Africa where the team scraped through the group stage after three moribund performances before losing 4-1 to Germany in the first knock-out round. Joachim Löw’s team may have been convincing winners in Bloemfontein but Capello maintains the outcome would have been different had Frank Lampard’s shot that hit the bar and crossed the line at 2-1 stood. Pressure for goalline technology intensified after the failure of the Uruguay referee Jorge Larrionda and his assistant Mauricio Espinosa to spot that Lampard’s effort had landed more than a foot behind Manuel Neuer’s line and the facility is now in place in Brazil. And the Russia manager, speaking before his side’s opening game against South Korea in Cuiaba on Tuesday, says his last World Cup experience should be considered in that context. Asked if his approach to this World Cup had changed as a consequence of England’s failure in South Africa, the 67-year-old on £6.7m a year replied; “I haven’t changed things, it is Fifa that have changed things. It was my England team that was punished four years ago and everybody knows what a great difference in makes in a game when you go from 2-0 to 2-2. When I think about four years ago I go back to that result. What happened then helped the case for goalline technology but it was England who paid the price for the technology that is now out there.”
